natural problem:
Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles.
natural solution: We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\

&= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> theta. M = (\<chi> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 + sin theta else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 1 + cos theta else 1)"
shows  "Max {determinant M |theta. - pi \<le> theta \<and> theta \<le> pi} = 1/2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> theta. M = (\<chi> i j. if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 + sin theta else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 1 + cos theta else 1)"
shows  "Max {determinant M |theta. - pi \<le> theta \<and> theta \<le> pi} = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Consider a 3x3 matrix M, where each element is defined as follows: if both the row and column indices are 1, then the element is 1, if they are both 2, then the element is 1 plus the sine of an angle theta, if they are both 3, then the element is 1 plus the cosine of theta, and for all other elements, the value is 1. Find the maximum determinant of M, as theta varies from -π to π. The answer is 1/2.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix (\<lambda> (i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 + sin theta else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 1 + cos theta else 1)"
shows  "Max {det M |M. \<forall> theta. -pi \<le> theta \<and> theta \<le> pi} = 1/2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix (\<lambda> (i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 + sin theta else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 1 + cos theta else 1)"
shows  "Max {det M |M. \<forall> theta. -pi \<le> theta \<and> theta \<le> pi} = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider a 3x3 matrix M, defined by M = [[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin(theta), 1], [1, 1, 1 + cos(theta)]]. What is the maximum determinant of this matrix for all real numbers theta within the closed interval from -pi to pi? The final answer is 1/2.

a_2.formal problem:

fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> theta. M = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin theta, 1], [1 + cos theta, 1, 1]])"
shows  "Max (range (determinant M)) = 1/2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> theta. M = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin theta, 1], [1 + cos theta, 1, 1]])"
shows  "Max (range (determinant M)) = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given the matrix $M = \begin{{bmatrix}}1 & 1 & 1\\ 1 & 1+sin(\theta) & 1\\ 1+cos(\theta) & 1 & 1\end{{bmatrix}}$, what is the maximum value of the determinant of $M$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{2}$.

shows  "Max(det(M)) = 1/2"

fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>theta. M = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin(theta), 1], [1 + cos(theta), 1, 1]])"

assumes h0 : "\<forall> θ. M = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin(θ), 1], [1 + cos(θ), 1, 1]])"
shows  "max (Determinant M) = 1/2"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof

fixes θ :: real and M :: "real^3^3"

shows  "max (Determinant M) = 1/2"
 proof-

a_4.informal problem: Find the maximum value of the determinant of a 3x3 matrix $M$ that is defined as follows: the first row is [1, 1, 1], the second row is [1, 1 + sin(θ), 1], and the third row is [1 + cos(θ), 1, 1] for all real numbers θ. The final answer is 1/2.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes theta :: real and A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A theta = abs (1 + sin theta - cos theta)"
shows  "Max {A theta |theta. True} = 1/2"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

fixes theta :: real and A :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "A theta = abs (1 + sin theta - cos theta)"
shows  "Max {A theta |theta. True} = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the maximum value of the function $A(\theta) = |1 + \sin(\theta) - \cos(\theta)|$. The maximum value is $\frac{1}{2}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1
                                  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 1
                                  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then 1
                                  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 1
                                  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 + sin theta
                                  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 1
                                  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then 1 + cos theta
                                  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 1
                                  else 1)"
shows  "Max {det M |theta. - pi \<le> theta \<and> theta \<le> pi} = 1/2"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes theta :: real and M :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then 1
                                  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 1
                                  else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then 1
                                  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then 1
                                  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 1 + sin theta
                                  else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 1
                                  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then 1 + cos theta
                                  else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then 1
                                  else 1)"
shows  "Max {det M |theta. - pi \<le> theta \<and> theta \<le> pi} = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Consider a 3 by 3 matrix M with each entry defined as follows:

- The entries at positions (1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (2,1), (2,3), and (3,2) are all equal to 1.
- The entry at position (2,2) is equal to 1 plus the sine of a real number theta.
- The entry at position (3,1) is equal to 1 plus the cosine of theta.
- The entry at position (3,3) is simply 1.

Now, find the maximum determinant of M as theta varies from negative pi to pi. The final answer is 1/2.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes \<theta> :: real
and matrix :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "matrix \<theta> = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin \<theta>, 1], [1 + cos \<theta>, 1, 1]])"
shows  "1/2 = (GREATEST x. \<exists> \<theta>. x = det(matrix \<theta>))"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes \<theta> :: real
and matrix :: "real \<Rightarrow> real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "matrix \<theta> = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin \<theta>, 1], [1 + cos \<theta>, 1, 1]])"
shows  "1/2 = (GREATEST x. \<exists> \<theta>. x = det(matrix \<theta>))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix where the elements are defined as follows: the first row is all 1s, the second row is [1, 1 + sin(θ), 1], and the third row is [1 + cos(θ), 1, 1]. What is the maximum possible determinant of this matrix? The final answer is 1/2.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes theta :: real and A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> theta. A = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin theta, 1], [1 + cos theta, 1, 1]])"
shows  "Max {det A | theta. True} = 1/2"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} &= \begin{vmatrix} 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix} - \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} + \begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 + \sin \theta \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes theta :: real and A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> theta. A = matrix([[1, 1, 1], [1, 1 + sin theta, 1], [1 + cos theta, 1, 1]])"
shows  "Max {det A | theta. True} = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the maximum determinant value of a $3 \times 3$ matrix $A$, where $A$ is defined for every real number $\theta$ as $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin\theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos\theta & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$. The maximum determinant value is $\frac{1}{2}$.

theorem
fixes theta :: real
and A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[1,1,1], [1,1 + sin theta,1], [1 + cos theta,1,1]])"
shows  "Max (eigenvalues A) = 1/2"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the maximum value of
\[\begin{vmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 1 + \sin \theta & 1 \\ 1 + \cos \theta & 1 & 1 \end{vmatrix},\]as $\theta$ ranges over all angles. The final Answer is \frac{1}{2}

 &= ((1 + \sin \theta) - 1) - (1 - (1 + \cos \theta)) + (1 - (1 + \sin \theta)(1 + \cos \theta)) \\ &= -\cos \theta \sin \theta = -\frac{2 \cos \theta \sin \theta}{2} = -\frac{\sin 2 \theta}{2}. \end{align}The maximum value of the determinant is then $\boxed{\frac{1}{2}}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes theta :: real
and A :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[1,1,1], [1,1 + sin theta,1], [1 + cos theta,1,1]])"
shows  "Max (eigenvalues A) = 1/2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a 3x3 matrix A, where A = [[1,1,1], [1,1 + sin(theta),1], [1 + cos(theta),1,1]], find the maximum eigenvalue of A. The maximum eigenvalue is 1/2.
